title: 115_hr6040
content: The Act is titled the "Contra Costa Canal Transfer Act" and includes definitions for various terms used within the Act. The "Contra Costa Canal Transfer Act" defines terms such as "acquired land" as federal land for the Contra Costa Canal project and "Contra Costa Canal Agreement" as the agreement between the District and the Bureau of Reclamation for the transfer of the canal. The Contra Costa Canal Transfer Act involves compensating the reclamation fund for the transfer of the Contra Costa Canal Unit of the Central Valley Project to the Contra Costa Water District in California. The Contra Costa Canal Transfer Act in California includes various infrastructure elements like pipelines, pumping plants, and regulatory facilities. It excludes the Rock Slough fish screen facility. The term "contracts" refers to existing water service contracts between the District and the United States. The Contra Costa Canal Transfer Act in California includes infrastructure elements like pipelines, pumping plants, and regulatory facilities. The Act excludes the Rock Slough fish screen facility, which is defined as the fish screen facility at the Rock Slough intake to the Contra Costa Canal. This facility includes the screen structure, rake cleaning system, and accessory structures integral to its function as required by the Central Valley Project Improvement Act. The Rock Slough fish screen facility title transfer agreement involves the transfer of the facility between the District and the Bureau of Reclamation to ensure its safe and reliable operations. The Secretary refers to the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 3. CONVEYANCE OF LAND AND FACILITIES. The Secretary shall offer to convey and assign to the District all right, title, and interest of the United States in the Contra Costa Canal and acquired land, in consideration for assuming liability for administration and maintenance. The Secretary will convey the Rock Slough fish screen facility to the District as part of the Contra Costa Canal transfer agreement. The District will negotiate with the Secretary within 180 days for the conveyance. The District is responsible for paying any associated costs. The District will pay administrative and real estate transfer costs to the Secretary for conveyances and assignments, including surveys and appraisals. Before the transfer, the Secretary must comply with environmental laws such as the National Environmental Policy Act and the Endangered Species Act. The Act does not change obligations under the National Environmental Policy Act or the Endangered Species Act. SEC. 4. RELATIONSHIP TO EXISTING CENTRAL VALLEY PROJECT CONTRACTS. The Act does not affect reclamation laws for water delivery to the District under contracts with the Secretary. The contracts can be modified to comply with the Act. The United States is not liable for damages related to the Contra Costa Canal, except for acts of negligence before the conveyance date. The Act does not increase the liability of the United States beyond what is provided under the Federal Tort Claims Act. SEC. 5. REPORT. If conveyance and assignment not completed within 1 year, Secretary must report to Congress on status, obstacles, and anticipated completion date.
